This is a replica of a pistol ring. This is not a toy nor a real firearm. This can be used as a prop or just to look cool. The dimensions of the ring theoretically should hold .22 long rifle rounds, but I am uncertain if it actually does. The regular "Pistol Ring" file is a size seven ring, whereas the "S8" version is a size eight ring. I will be working on different sizes in the near future. Note: I am not responsible for the actions and consequences that you will face if you decide to print this prop.
Slide the cylinder through the center rod of the ring and glue the cylinder plug into the center hole of it. Make sure the cylinder rotates freely.

author: ederosa

description.text:
Work in progress, did not print as one even with full support (did not really see any support actually).  Will have to break into 4 parts perhaps to make it really printable.
Derivatives of others people work of course, I will also be adding links to their parts as soon as I figure things out.
First print was a failure; however, it was interesting so I posted it as well.

This is a reasonably accurate model of the Saturn I-B rocket used to launch low-earth-orbit Apollo missions (Apollo 5 (LM test), Apollo 7, Skylab 2,3, and 4, and ASTP).  
Some liberties were taken in various places to allow for spiral printing (apart from the base).
The photos show three printed models done during scad development sitting next to a commercial injection-molded saturn 1b rocket model for comparison (which I started assembly on when I was about 12 years old...).

To spiral print this chose a location to split the model and print both halves.  The example in the photos was split just above the S-1B stage.  The S-IVB and apollo section was printed right-side-up.  The S-1B was printed upside-down.  Sadly Cura will not close the top of a spiral print, so the engines won't print using this approach. You'll have to print them separately if you want them.

Make your own Destiny ship! Each ship typically has a cockpit, nacelle, rocketlauncher, antenna, and engine (sometimes a body is required to complete the gaps). These are a bunch of models of different sections of different Destiny ships. Grab several, and merge them in Meshlab (http://meshlab.sourceforge.net/). File->Import Mesh->select files. Filter->Mesh Layers->Flatten Visible Layers. Then File->Export Mesh As-> name file and section/support and print! EDIT: Please note thanks to the work of Brent Peterson and reddit.com/u/potatob there is an STL generator for getting stls from the destinydb.com site (they can't be mixed and matched, but will have lots of models to work with): http://www.destinystlgenerator.com/

3D Printable Morphling from the game Dota 2 by Valve.
I cut the model so it would print without support material but the head stil requires it, I will re-cut in the future.

For dark eons the comet circled. Held in thrall to a distant sun, bound by gravity’s inexorable pull, the massive ball of ice careened through the blackness between worlds, made strange by its dark journey. On the eve of the ancient war of the Vloy, it punched down through the sky and lit a glowing trail across the night, a sign both armies took for an omen. The frozen ball melted in a flash of boiling heat, as below two forces enjoined in battle across the border of a narrow river. Thus freed from its icy stasis, the Morphling was born into conflict, an elemental power at one with the tides of the ocean, capricious and unconstrained. He entered the fight, instinctively taking the form of the first general who dared set foot across the water, and then struck him dead. As the motley warriors clashed, he shifted from form to form throughout the battle, instantly absorbing the ways of these strange creatures--now a footsoldier, now an archer, now the cavalryman--until, by the time the last soldier fell, Morphling had played every part. The battle's end was his beginning.

Credits to Valve Corporation for the original 3D file and image.

The seat adjusting levers on my 1995 Toyota Corolla Seca have very sharp edges.  It is very easy to snag your leg on a lever when entering or leaving the car.  Quite possibly the car originally came with protective knobs on the levers, but these are long gone.  
I designed and made this very simple knob to protect occupants' legs from injury.  It is fully customisable in OpenSCAD.  Adjust the ID, OD and length to suit your particular application.  Needs to be a snug fit on the lever.
Printed on a Makerbot Replicator 1 Dual at 90/150 mm/s, 0.2 mm layer thickness, 2 shells, 10% infill, raft and no supports.

author: joesow

title: Fortis Titan Gopro Zip tie mount

description.text:
I made this mount up so you can mount a gopro to your Fortis Titan frame and not drill any extra holes. The slots are 35MM center to center.   
Update: turns out the source file wasn't ideal so the spacing between the ams is a little to wide/the bolt hole isn't the same so i will adjust soon. In the meantime I just x-acto knife cut the bolt holes off and it fits perfectly. I hope to come up with a design that has a soft pad underneath to soak up the vibrations of flight.   
UPDATE: Added the "gopro_fortis_zip_tie_1" updated file. This one isn't as visually appealing and lacks the area to hold the nut which I will work on fixing soon but it gives a much lower mount if what your after is a VERY low profile mount to keep your COG down.

Printed in XT filament at .2 layers, 25% fill and 235C, .8MM sides and 1mm top and bottom on my Ultimaker 2. Adjust settings per your printers requirements. XT or ABS preferred since PLA is a bit to stiff albeit you can print in PLA at your own risk!

title: flexible filament adapter for solidoodle 4 extruder

description.text: helps guild the flexible filament like filaflex or ninja flex through the extruder into the hot end

i printed it with 80 percent infill most likely ended up being 100% due to the small size also i printed it out of nylon hoping nylons properties would come into play of being low friction,   
it was difficult due to the fact that nylon stays gooey between layers and i don't know how to put a min time between layers so i printed out 4 of them to fix that issue, (i broke 1 trying to install it because i forgot to pull the filament out, or remove the bolt that i made a clearance hole for the socket head cap )  
also rotate in x 90 deg to print it out easily.  
may need cleaning up or small about of trimming to allow clearance for moving parts  
it does work i have been printing with filaflex and haven't had any issues

author: Kestr

description.text:
Parametric Lego Mindstorms Omniwheel. The OmniwheelSolid can be printed without any support structures. Needed Parts: 8x Barrel 1x OmniwheelSolid 8x Lego Axle 3L (length=23 mm, PartNr 4519) Also added are the files with name containing the word "_printable". These files have been slightly modified so that my 3D printer prints them more accurately. remark:
The base of the omniwheel has been printed in ABS. The barrels have been printed in Ninjaflex, which works quite well in preventing the slipping of the barrels on smooth surfaces. The omniwheels in action:
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9vQ3zvjawTM&feature=youtu.be For an alternative version (82 mm wheels) of this design see:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1187412

• The axle holes have been drilled to a diameter of 5.0 mm
  • The top/bottom holes have been drilled to a diameter of 4.8 mm

comments.text: The files without the name "_printable" are exact measurements. To get the omniwheel better out of my printer (Prusa i3) I had to make some changes: compare files "OmniwheelSolid2.scad" and "OmniwheelSolid2_printable.scad". But these are just minor changes. This omniwheel can be easily printed on a Prusa i3 printer as can be seen from the images. The only special printer setting is the use of a brim, no supports/ no rafts. The first layer I print with object cooling system disabled; all other layers are printed with the object cooling system running at maximum. (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:357833)
comments.author: SquareD

comments.text: I am assuming that you are printing with ABS.  I am printing with PLA.  My finished rollers are 14.93mm dia. and 14.24mm tall.  What size are yours?  A lego axle is 4.71mm wide.  The hole in the roller is 5.67mm.  I printed a 85% roller and it is a friction fit.  I am almost done with 2 full sets of wheels and I will let you know if it works.
comments.author: projunk

comments.text: Yes, I am printing both chassis and rollers in ABS. The friction fit with the axle in the roller is quite easy to achieve in ABS. My finished roller dimensions (14,4 mm tall, 15.4 mm diameter). I did print all parts with 100% infill. I used the "_printable" files, which are of course suited for my own Prusa i3. Intentionally I made the axle holes in the "_printable" smaller so that i can make them fit using a 5 mm drill. When I was printing the first test print using "bigger" axle holes, the bearings did crack due to cooling down of the ABS; printing smaller holes fixed that issue. Since you are using PLA, that should not be an issue at all.
comments.author: SquareD

comments.text:
The axles are alum. and they both free spin but the metal axles do spin a little better. I am going to try and test the wheels today and maybe make another set.
I used 2 shells and 10% infill on my prints and it worked fine. Took about 4 hours to print.
I will post videos to Youtube so you can see.

description.text: The reality is that my second extruder is never used and only causes me problems when servicing and more mass to move. I love NeverDun design (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:551916), it eliminates the second extruder using their space to add a cooling fan. remixed_from.author: CreativeTools
remixed_from.title: Adjustable Drive Block Upgrade for Replicator 2 and 1

description.text: So the designs that all reclaim to help extrude ninjaflex don't really work, or they have some space where the filament can escape (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:42250), or they are adjustable with a screw (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:136589) - this is a remix of these two (keeping the spring, enclosing the filament guide hole), plus I added a tiny blocking part under the gear wheel to avoid ninjaflex doubling up and passing under the gear - the ninjaflex is now completely supported and guided on all sides from the pinch point to the hotend entry hole - you probably still need to avoid almost any retraction at all (still to test with larger retractions), but I can now print varios parts at once, when before this caused the filament to snag after a couple of layers (heat creep + filament doubling under the wheel).
Recommended ABS (for heat resistance)

comments.text: This extruder body helps when the flexible filament goes under the Mk7 drive wheel - there is a tiny protrusion in just the right place to avoid this..  you can only try and see with the current extruder ;-)

Most basic but very well working extruder. One piece with a Mk7 drive gear and a idler bearing.
it's solid, it's simple and it just works.

Print the part, mount a 624 idler bearing (4x13x5) with a M4 screw. Mount the motor with the Mk7 drive gear and adjust the position of the motor to adjust the tension on the filament. You want it to make clearly visible indentations in the filament. Mount on standard 50mm carriage. Never look back. The part is modeled in SpaceClaim, but I have added all the CAD formats I could export, so everybody should be able to modify it. See it in action here:
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5WO72VkRDMI
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7nXVlg__FlA
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0fKpK1GCtgU

title: Fan duct for 30x30x10mm fan for the kossel clear fan mount

description.text:
This fan duct is valid for every 30x30x10 fan, but the lenghts are designed for the Kossel clear fan mount:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:372568 This duct is for cooling the extruder. Whithout it, the aire blown by the fan goes to the nozzle, cooling it too, in a way that it's impossible to reach more than 250ºC and slowing the heating. The purpouse of the fan is avoiding the heat going up through the extruder body and preventing the jamming of the plastic or damaging the extruder itself, I think. Enjoy! Maybe if you have wires from the resistance (heater) and thermistor, you will have to cut a chamfer to the closest part of the nozzle.

I made it with 0,2mm layer, 35%infill, with 0,5mm nozzle and 4700mm/min printing speed and 75% speed outlines. I always use 2mm brim to avoid wrapping.  
Fix it with M3x16 screws, it have two holes to put the hex, but I fount that they are unnecessary.

author: Pezzi33

description.text:
da Vinci 1.0. "cartridge-plug" for use with an Arduino MICRO or UNO to reset cartridge counter. If you follow my description i'm not responsable for your faults or occuring damages. You may damage your pc, printer and arduino, or wathever you use and may loose your warranties. The resetting works only with earlier FW-versions of daVinci 1.0 (think before 1.2.3), but you can downgrade your daVinci just looking for the bossac-tool (manual version) or xyzdowngrader (automatic version) in Voltivo forum or other places. Only go on, when your FW fits the needs. You can also buy several version of resetting hardware and tools on voltivo-website. Here is my alternative (using FW 1.1.J):
  • Print the plug (maybe you have to widen the holes for the springpins - depends on your hardware)
  • Solder some wires on the pins, press them in the holes and connect them to your preferred Arduino.
  • Prepare your Arduino ...
    The Arduino is programmed with Arduino IDE 1.5.8 and script from Voltivo (found in GitHub: https://github.com/voltivo or Voltivo forum).
  • Use USB-Power or other, depends on your needs, and put the plug on your cartridge-counter. A few seconds later (watch LED) your counter will be reset.
    • Printer works pretty good with non-xyz filament, but will fail with an error if lenght-parameter in Arduino script is set >240m (maybe depend on FW). In a future version all the stuff will be inserted in a dummy cartridge and resetting will be done by using a simple switch (LED indicates ON/OFF and READY-status) to turn from reading into programming mode. You will not have to remove the inserted cartdridge nor switch the printer off ... Update: Now it's done - All the stuff fits in a dummy cartridge and works like described above. The connector is now no longer required, a small custom built pcb-board makes the connection between cartridge ( counter ) and printer. The printer works very well with filament from different manufacturers. In cooperation with the FW 1.1.J and Simplify3D printing with ABS and PLA filament works, too. The only thing that remains is that the counter has to be reset after 240m of filament. Update: Maybe the newest modification inspire you on your way to experiment with your Da Vinci 1.0. There are a few small modifications: An externally accessible reset button and direct access to the SD card. Thus, experiments with different FW are very simple and it also opens up the possibility to use a WiFi SD card or replace the SD card
ABS print in medium quality with 3 layers , 2 perimeters and 20-25 % infill will fit your needs

comments.text: i got everything but the switch. what kind of switch is or how did you make? Please tell me!! PIX?of the inside of the dummy.thanks

comments.text:

comments.author: joshchretien

comments.text: Welcome ... I've added a small sketch that you might find useful.
comments.author: joshchretien

comments.text: I moreso am wondering how you got the chip to be re programmable while remaining in the printer. It's a small photo, did you solder the leads direct to the chip in the cartridge? And if so does this effect the printer detection?
comments.author: joshchretien

comments.text: I made a litte tab pcb which replaces the counter at the bottom of the cartridge (small right pic). The switch in the middle, near LED, switches between NORMAL mode (means: printing) and PROGRAMMING mode (means: cutting off the contacts between printer tab and counter pcb, and connecting arduino with counter). Switching between the modes is the same as changing cartridges. The masterswitch on the left powers the programming arduino with 9V and is only allowed to be switched in PROGRAMMING mode! When programming is done (LED inicates) the arduino must be powered off with the masterswitch. Only then NORMAL mode has to be selected (means: connect cartrigde to the printer again) - that's it, quick'n dirty
comments.author: joshchretien

comments.text: What do you use to control these temps? As I understand you are still running stock firmware?
comments.author: joshchretien

comments.text:
Hi,
this is right - but now i use Simplify3D to control the printer with stock FW (imho the best version see thing info), not XYZware.
comments.author: joshchretien

comments.text: Do you have the plans for the finished product with custom dummy cartridge? This is sweet!
comments.author: joshchretien

comments.text:
Hi,
thank you for your interest ... i have no further plans with itself, because it's only a little step on the way to get my daVinci free from the manufacturer restrictions (maybe faster than they will do this). Now I can print a variety of materials (ABS, PLA, Nylon and other), because i control the temperature (bed and extruder) and I'm free where to buy my filament. Next step is to modify the extruder to be able to print transparent materials. After that I'll try to replace the firmware - this will make the dummy cartridge obsolete, but to have one means that I can always fallback to this step which works pretty well for me.
comments.author: joshchretien

author: wstein

title: N Scale model Railroad Railway Platform

description.text:
This is a model railroad platform for N scale with a ramp at one side and a set of stairs in the middle. Assembling the support poles onto the platform and the roof on the supports requires glue. The overall dimensions are 25 mm wide, 180 mm long and around 35mm high at the ridge of the roof. All has been constructed with Tinkercad, so if you would like to tweak and enhance, please feel free to play and re-share: Roof: https://tinkercad.com/things/iqhl1ORaAgw
Base: https://tinkercad.com/things/hW468qR47zS
Supports: https://tinkercad.com/things/1SeRt7TMoI4 Picture is along Kato Unitrack, which has quite a high bedding and is the system we use at home. Using other systems you will almost certainly need a lower platform. Modification 12/27/2014: Platform base changed to save some material and print faster :)

One file each for roof, platform and supports. Print two supports!  
Use some model builder glue to fix the supports to the base and the roof to the supports.   
Enjoy, build and share!

description.text:
Mobius HD anti vibration mount for multirotors. Mount hole pattern created specificly for the r.250 FPV quadcopter from Untestedprototype.com, but will work with other multirotors too. Easy access to USB port for charging and/or video out. SD card slot is covered, so it can not accidently pop out. Works with standard- and wide angle lens cams. Update 02.23.2015: Version 1.2 with lens protection for type "A" lens added
Update 01.27.2016: Version 1.4 with beefed up lens protection for type "B" and "C" added

No support needed, maximum overhangs 45°. Files already "NetFabbed" and in right orientation for printing.
Printed in PET, 2 shells, 50% infill

description.text:
This is a Case for the Antenna of the RDM6300 RFID reader. It is intended to be placed at doors for entrance. Because of security only the antenna should be placed outside not the whole hardware!  
This model was made with SolidWorks 2014.

Print top and bottom at 0.2 layer height without support.
The Models should be rotated by 90 degrees, so that the "face" is on the bed.
Place the antenna in the top and close the case with the bottom.
At the bottom there are two holes right and left for the cable. These were cut "around the corner", so that you can pull the cable out at the back or the bottom.
If you need more holes at different places, just let me know and i can upload them. If you made one, I would love to see pictures of them! ;-)

I had found that the feeder was not attracting a large clientele and what was needed was better advertising. Nine out of 10 birds surveyed indicated that they either appreciated the advertising signage or were indifferent to it! Plus I always try to personalize my 3D prints especially if I am giving them as gifts. I used the text feature on sketchup which can be a little tricky to embed it into the model until you learn the intersect faces feature :>). Enclosed is a model with a blank board and one I created as a gift. This is a remix of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:301787 so you will need to get the rest of the files from there.

4th_plate = rocker
5th_plate = none
2nd_plate_bottom_hole = none
plate_width = 4
1st_plate_bottom_hole = none
plate_size = 2
1st_plate = toggle
3rd_plate = toggle

I had extra 3/4 copper pipe laying around and decided to use it to hang few spools of filament above my printer.   
You can change hole diameter or make it square in Freecad - just modify first sketch there to use what you have.  
I made hole diameter slightly larger to accommodate my printer's tendency to make holes smaller - as a result pipe fits with slight resistance, which makes it hold whole assembly very well.  
I printed it with 50% infill and 0.5mm wall thickness. I also tried both 15 and 10 mms part thickness - both seems to work well for me, but i feel like 15mm is better. Again, you can adjust it all in Freecad.  
I got some warping issues with corners, so you might wat to add brim.  
You need to print at least two of these.

title: 3dpBurner. 3D printed laser cutter/engraver
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
NOTE: The files contained here are for 3dpBurner first version. Check http://3dpburner.blogspot.com for the newer 3dpBurner2. 3dpBurner is an open source laser cutter/engraver.
It is created with the same RepRap concept, using 3D printed parts and some easy to find "vitamins" (not printed hadware). I tried to do it as cheap as possible, by using cheap electronics
and a "low power" laser (a laser diode).
The X/Y working area is fully customizable and the max working object height is up to 50-60mm. You can check http://3dpburner.blogspot.com for more details. NOTE: It is imperative you get the apropiate protection for your eyes and prevent the toxic fumes released by the most of materials. First thing you need to buy prior to powering your laser is a pair of glasses adecuated to your laser wave lengh. The laser spot or laser reflections can hurt your eyes very easily. Avoid to use invisible diodes as IR laser diodes, they are more dangerous due you can not see when they are powered. You can see some works here: http://3dpburner.blogspot.com/p/videos.html Sep/17/2015: NEW VERSION UPDATE!. Added a 3dpBurner2 picture. Check the 3dpBurner2 page of the blog for more info. Apr/27/2015: After some months and many tests, the 3dpBurner has been proved to be stable and rock solid, producing very good results, so the design is considered full finished now :) Jun/18/2015: Laser Driver bumper is for the WalyePower model laser driver. If your WalyePower PCB board is larger you can break the unfinished cutting tab (some sellers send it with this tab). Dec/28/2014: Added "walyePowerLaserDriveBumper.STL" and "ArduinoUNObumperPlain.STL" files. Videos: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=10mtTxxuomQ https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=JqyotXOw7E0 https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=v1f7wb4RKRg

These are the recomended print settings: Printed on .STL file position, using ABS without supports. baseMountTypeA.STL----x2----Infill 50%
baseMountTypeB.STL----x2----Infill 50%
fanDuct.STL-----------------x1----Infill 50%
fanMount.STL---------------x1----Infill 50%
xIdler.STL--------------------x1----Infill 50%
xIdlerMount.STL------------x1----Infill 50%
xMotorMount.STL----------x1----Infill 50%
yBeltHolder.STL------------x1----Infill 50%
yIdler.STL--------------------x1----Infill 50%
yLimitHolder.STL-----------x1----Infill 50%
yMotorMount.STL----------x1----Infill 50%
xCarriageNutHolder.STL--x2----Infill 50% xIdlerBridge.STL------------x1----Infill 90%
xMotorBridge.STL----------x1----Infill 90%
xCarriageV4.STL-----------x1---.Infill 90% gauge50mm.STL-----------x1----Infill 20%
walyePowerLaserDriveBumper.STL---x1----Infill 20%
ArduinoUNObumperPlain.STL---x1----Infill 20% Check the blog for full details and instructions: http://3dpburner.blogspot.com

comments.text: I am using CNC Shield v3.0.  The PWM signal is being drawn from the Z+ pin.  When the laser is off I have 3V across the pins and at M3 S255 I have 5V.  I am using what I believe to be the previous version of firmware from 3dpburner.blogspot.com (I downloaded it 12-4-2016).

comments.text: If anyone else runs into this same problem...  I eventually figured out that the PWM from the Arduino was faulty.  M3 S0 should yield 0V across the Z+ pin, not 3V.  A new UNO R3 and CNC shield later, it works like a dream.  Thanks again for the design and tutorial, so awesome to have my own laser engraver!

I have some problems with resolution. In theori I have 20016=3200 steps/rev. With 20 teeth T2 pully that makes 3200/202=80 steps/mm.
That is also the normal number for GRBL where I have the following:
$100=80.000 (x, step/mm)
$101=80.000 (y, step/mm)

comments.text: Good day , everyone gathered and set up . But I can not figure out how to use the program , namely, how to display the laser to the desired point me to start printing , I bring and he then goes where he pleases . and the second question in a program format and create images for print . If you can video printing process from the beginning to the end of the show . Thank you
comments.author: antonkopa

comments.text:
First, you have to move the laser head to your desired starting point with the application arrows. I usually take the down left corner as my 0,0 starting point. It depends on your design.
Then turn on the laser filling the camp near the PWR button with a low number i.e: 5. Click PWR button and then ON button (must do in this order).
Make any fine adjustments of the starting position and click ZERO XY button to tell the application that this will be their new 0,0 coordinates.
Finally click SEND FILE to start burning
For the images to print visit http://3dpburner.blogspot.com.es/p/files.html and download Image2Gcode application developed by Villamany. It's a simple but powerful tool to burn images, and is optimized for 3dpburner.

comments.text: I got mine tuned up today. I never could get the light to turn off with the meter hooked up to read voltage. I went ahead and hooked it up to read current(short) and was seeing about 3 amps. I turned the current adjustment counter clockwise and saw the current reading start to go down. It takes many turns but you will see the light turn off once you get around the one amp range .I was afraid to kill my meter so I would turn laser on, adjust for a few seconds,then turn off with gcode sender laser on/off button. Once you get the current low enough to shut the light off, you can connect the laser with the meter in series for current reading. Turn laser on and adjust current to final value of 1.65 amps.

comments.text: I was having trouble with jerky movement during my first test run. It turned out to be a bad oversight on my part. I looked at photos and saw that the stepper drivers had three jumpers in to enable microstepping. My drivers did not come with any jumpers so were set to full step by default. Once I got the jumpers and set them all was smooth.
comments.author: mikebaier

comments.text:
Maybe some bearing is damaged due to shock or dirty.
Usually I get a smoother movement a few days after having mounted the machine when all this shot.
You can try cleaning and lubricating inside bearings (i use PTFE oil). On one of my machines had to replace two bearings (it was hearing "click" at high speeds).
comments.author: mikebaier

comments.text:
3dpBurner Sender uses rapid movments for "manual jogging". Type $$ and press enter on console. You will see all configurable parameters. If you type $110=6000 you will set the max X speed to 6000mm/s
Play with speeds and accelerations to fit your needs. The default values of 12000mm/min are ok for my 210x300 Working area.

comments.text: Im getting up to about 20000mm/min max speed on my setup, but lowered to 12000 for prevent shaking issues. Also the max speed im using for burning is only 2000-3000 mm/min with my 9mm 445nm laser, this speed is for picture engraving, for normal engraving is a lower speed... about 1000 -1500 for wood engraving, 210mm/min for 2mm eva foam cutting... so if you use similar laser 6000mm/min is more than enough. Im using these motors http://www.3dpburnershop.blogspot.com/p/mot.html

comments.text: Hrm... Looks like I might have a wiring difference (I did make it up....), just updated to your Grbl Firmware (After a hair ripping experience with Ubuntu and uploading), I have my laser hooked up to a normally open "NO" relay connected to the "Spindle Enable" on the Arduino Shield, No matter what I do now the Laser is on permanently.....How did you hook yours up to support "M03" & "M05"?
comments.author: villamany

comments.text: Use the zLimit pin instead the spindleEnable one. For variable spindle (variable laser power) feature you need to use this pin. Also if you are using a relay instead a variable laser driver type $N1=S255 this will ensure 100% dutty cycle for the relay. You can turn laser on with M3 command and M5 to turn it off. And if you use PWM capable driver Sx for set the laser power (S=0 to 255 = 0 to 100% laser power)

comments.text: I don't use it long enough but personally i'm using the 9mm 445nm diode from here https://sites.google.com/site/dtrlpf/home/diode-modules . Note that the seller claim to be a 3W diode and recomended me to use this diode at 2.4A for laser pointers and 2.2A for cotinuous usage on CNC machines. First try was at 2.1A. Pretty power but the cooling block get very hot after 5 min working time. Then I read the datasheet (download from the same seller page) and the reality is: Absolute maximum ratting recommended by the manufacturer is 1.7A !! at this current the diode put out about 1.6-2W. So the seller is overdriving the diode a lot to get 3W. I set my driver down to 1.65A and repeat all tests. At this power no overheating is noticed and it is working well enough after 3h of continuous use. I have booth lens, the 3 elements glass one and the G2. The 3 elements one (cheaper) is much better for this purpose (less optical power but more concentrated).
comments.author: villamany

description.text: Star Wars Dagobah playset crate, container
Page marker. Tested!

Case for the popular LED cubes, fits the 4x4x4 kit that is widely available on eBay and other places. My board is 82mm square and the hole centres are about 73mm. A STEP file is available in the downloads.

Print the base in the STL file and cut the parts in the DXF on a laser machine from 2mm acrylic. Bolt the circuit board to the base, glue the acrylic panels into a box and slip it over the LEDs. There is room for a 9 volt battery in the base and a position for a switch or pushbutton in the front.
This insert goes into the bottom of R2-D2 for the Dagobah playset.  It allows R2 to levitate when you push down on the rock of the playset.

title: Remix of i3v 10" Prus Makerfarm X-Carriage with rounded corners & fillet welds

description.text: I liked the idea of having a spare part of this in plastic although I have read that it may have some problems with the plastic being too close to the hotend. I modified http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:481769 to have rounded corners & a little more support at the 90 connections of the plastic with 2 fillet welds. I uploaded a rev2 of this part after noticing the original that I remixed from was missing a hole for the gear shaft. I made this a symmetrical slotted hole to use less plastic. I have not printed the new part or tried it on my machine yet.
I printed this at 60% infill with a brim of 4 in PLA.  Since this would be better to print in ABS being close to the hot extruder, I will print it again in ABS when I have that filament loaded.

description.text:
I made this set for my buddy's kids. Goal 1: Make kids happy. Goal 2: Get them into chess. Goal 3: Have an excuse to make stuff and create a forthcoming augmentation to the most perfect game. I will be including a set of rules to help resolve encounters in chess with a Pocket-Tactics style dice mechanic very soon.  
I'm sure I've fractured all sorts of chess and Minecraft conventions in making this set. I apologize to any purists out there, but it was a fun albeit imperfect print. Also, thanks to everyone in the Thingiverse that makes Minecraft content! See remixed from for the STLs I used and modified to make this set.

All these pieces were printed at the MakerWare high quality default setting with ABS and then painted with spray paint. Some glue was used to assemble the bits, but that was pretty straight forward. Note: when gluing the Wither, beware where you grab as removing a super glued finger from the Wither will cause distress (trust me).

description.text:
Sometimes there is need for power supply and only thing with hand is old atx psu. It needs some tricks to start and molex connectors to use, if hacking all the wires are out of the question, help is here. With this little box all atx 1,0 compatible power supply's are now practical to use to somewhere else. With this version only limitation is +12V with only one wire from psu, do not over load this. I'm not going to tell you how to connect this, but I'm telling what you need: ATX 1.0 connector from old motherboard
Power switch suitable for 13X20 hole (might be 12X20)
5mm LED and suitable resistor (1K for 5V)
4 banana connectors for 5mm mounting holes
4 screws from old printer or somewhere... I will draw upgrade to this someday with molex connectors, so 12V can be used to maximum load.

A decorative thimble designed in TopMod, using the method described in the shotglass tutorial which is linked from the shotglass object:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:434
After TopMod (the .obj file), this was resized and converted to .dae using Meshlab so that it could be printed by Shapeways. Here is the object at Shapeways:
http://www.shapeways.com/model/27961/collector_s_thimble.html
This was basically my first attempt at 3D design; the tutorial was extremely helpful.
I'd be curious if anyone tries to print this with Makerbot or RepRap. One note is that it lacks the support between the inner and outer layers that is described in the shotglass tutorial, so I imagine that would need to be added. I think the thinnest surfaces and smallest gaps are a bit under 2mm. The outer dimensions are a bit large for a thimble; that was so that Shapeways could print it (my first attempt had been too thin).

Here is a simple bracket I designed to mount an old Iphone 4S on the end of my Ultimaker Original machine in order to make use of the time lapse feature added with IOS 8. Designed to hold an Iphone 4S however could be used with devices that do not exceed a depth of 10mm.  There are two holes which are given in order to secure the bracket using a size #6-32 machine screw however I found that it is not entirely necessary.   
*Important note, you'll find that you need to lock the auto-focus on the iphone, do this prior to hitting the shutter button, press and hold in the center of the screen until you see a yellow box appear and the letters AE/AF at the top of the screen, this indicates the autofocus is locked.

Print two of these brackets and secure to either the front or right side of an ultimaker original machine at the top of the machine where there is a slight amount of laser cut wooden material above the top plate. Slide the iPhone 4s between the two and adjust your camera viewing location for the print.

description.text:
THIS DESIGN HAS BEEN MOVED TO YOUMAGINE:
https://www.youmagine.com/designs/steadycam-mark-ii Reasons:
http://marcuswolschon.blogspot.de/2014/01/leaving-thingiverse.html Changes from Mark I:
  • handle below gimbal-assembly
  • handle offset to be on the axis of the center of gravity
  • handle free to yaw due to 2 608 ball bearings.
  • attachment of side-handle still possible and compatible with Gimbal Mark I
  • Gimbal Mark I can be upgraded by replacing "grip_v07" with "grip_v08"+"handle_v08". "inner" and "outher" are basically unaffected

See

for details, version history and assembly-instructions.

title: Vent, Flashforge Creator pro finger hole vent

description.text: In order to prevent fumes in your work area here is a vent that conveniently fits over the finger hole of the Flashforge Creator pro

over all this is easy to do don't let my instructions make it seem otherwise.  
This is designed to attach to a 4" dryer vent hose, and a fan to flow the air out. I used an old fan from an old projector the model DSB0624H (I was able to find a similar one from Mouser.com) or just keep the inside  fan diameter around 57mm. If the small screw holes don't fit just use silicone. To hold the vent adapter to the printer I designed it to be non-damaging to the printer my using tension to hold it on. On the inside of the printer use then wood with screw slightly longer than 1.5mm radius, because that is the radius of the screw hols.  
PS use tape to help seal the printer box just to help prevent air flow, and plastic wrap where the cables go in to the printer.

title: Flash Forge Creator Dual / PowerSpec 3D Pro Carriage Mk 5

description.text: This is the mk 4 version of my replacement Carriage for the Flashforge Creator Pro and similar dual-extruder printers.

Update 1:  Mk 1 turned out to be VERY problematic to assemble due to the interlocking parts.  Tolerances are likely too tight to build like this.  I redesigned to use long M3 bolts to assemble the main body, and changed the way the Y-Axis belt is clamped down from a separate piece to an integrated zip tie channel  
Update 2: Mk 2 printed well but had a few issues. The Y-Axis belt would rub against the bottom, so I thinned out the design creating a channel for the bottom of the Y-Axis belt.  the bolt holes where repositioned and countersunk to use 30mm M3 Hex Socket-head bolts (common to find at any good R/C car/plane store like Hobby Town USA).  I also fixed an issue with the strip tie channels so they align properly this time.  
Update 3: Mk 3 printed well, but the multiple pieces turns out to be a bad idea as it can cause slight misalignments in the bearings.  I decided to largely start over with a 1 part design.  This one should be printed inverted with support on.  No bolts are needed for this design, and the Y-Axis belt is secured with 2 strip ties in the center of the carriage instead of on the outside of it.  Honeycomb manual infil has been put in the cross-bar sections for strength and to reduce weight.  
Update 4:  The mk 4 had to be thinned down to allow for the wires behind the heater blocks, and the zip-tie Y-belt clam turned out to be difficult to tighten properly. The Mk 5 has had sufficient room built in for the cabling and a replacement Y-axis belt clamp has been replaced with a clamp that requires 2 M3 10mm bolts to secure.  The bolts that secure the heat spreader need to be replaced with M3 15mm bolts instead of the 10mm that are stock due to the thicker crossbeam.  
The Y-Axis belt clamp does take some cleanup from the support material to properly fit, but it goes together quite well.  
This model has been installed and is printing very well! (see pictures)  
Print with ABS, 2.0mm layer, 30% infil (experimental still).  Mk. 4 does require support to be printed properly (inverted)  
The original mk 1-4 files are zipped up here for storage in you want to browse the development process.  
This is still in test phase.  Input or comments much appreciated.  
I'm working on an additional version that will be much lighter and thinner.  
I intend on making this the basis for a full Bowden Extruder and laser etcher interchangeable print head upgrades once I'm sure this functions well as a replacement carriage.

title: 70mm Wheel for Economy Gearbox
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
These wheels are designed to fit the "economy" or "low cost" plastic gear motors and is aimed at Mini-Sumo and small robots with rubber band tyres.  
This remix is aimed at the #84 bands and is 70mm diameter to give clearance on a battery box mounted below the gearbox.

This wheel was designed on Creo Elements, and printed on a Printrbot Simple Metal using Repetier Host with Slicer.  
These wheels are sized to fit #84 rubbers bands with a 10% stretch but multiple narrower bands could be used.  
It's pictured with a couple of bands overlaid to make up the diameter until we modify our chassis.  
The Printrbot equipment was made available by Tanghall Smart Tech Club in York, England.

comments.text: Simple design and easy to print when you turn it and put it flat. IT also fits a DC motor perfectly.

This is used to mount a stepper motor to a Brutstruder. It was originally designed to use TheRuttmeister's 'older' gears ( thingiverse.com/thing:5164 ), however it could be adjusted to support any gear set you want. The stepper motor mounting holes have some 'slide' to them, so slightly different sized gears should work ok. I plan on updating this later to make sure it supports TheRuttmeister's new COLOSO-Gears ( http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:5795 ). The OpenSCAD file contains references to the following STL files (used for the assembly view and reference only, no STL's are used in the actual construction of the stepper mount):
  • Gears from thingiverse.com/thing:5164
  • BrutStruder block and idler from thingiverse.com/thing:4036
  • Dino-2 L&R from thingiverse.com/thing:1912
    • Putting these STL's in the same folder as the OpenSCAD file will allow you to see the pieces in an assembled view (like the multi-colored image on the left). UPDATE (02/07/11): Updated SCAD file, added 606 bearing STL's and single layer variants. My first print curled a bit at the corners, but was still usable. I tried adding some 'tabs' at the corners to increase the raft size (if used) and help hold down the corners. Just clip them off when done. They are untested, but should help, in theory ;-).

Pick and print a variant that best suits your needs (or modify the SCAD). Clip off the 'raft-tabs' if you used one of those variants.
You will need a 608 or 606 bearing to help support the big gear's shaft/bolt. The bolt is M6, so you'll need to shim it up to M8 if you use the 608 version. I used some kapton tape. 
This is a large print (~87mm in Y), so be sure the platform is well centered when you start printing. If you use a raft, check the Skeinforge output to make sure it doesn't go beyond the build platform.

comments.text: can anyone recommend a different gear set for this? Theruttmeister has pulled his files. I got my hands on an early Cupcake CNC that I am trying to upgrade.
comments.author: Apru

comments.text: I can attest that TheRuttmeister's new 51 and 7 tooth gears v1.1 (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:5795)http://www.thingiverse.com/thi... work very well with this. I had a problem with the heat of my stepper motor softening the adapter plate (PLA). ABS may work better. I cut a crude version out of MDF and added a cooling fan. Just the fan may be sufficient, because it makes the motor cool enough to hold a finger to, rather than being too hot to touch.

comments.text: Looks like its because you have such a small stepper... I'm running something thats close to the size of the standard cupcake motors and I can keep the current low enough (and still extrude at stupid speeds) that the motor never gets more than skin temperature.

remixed_from.title: Marble race - 00 .junction track (needed to connect rails)

description.text:
Basic Hollow track for marble race. dimensions:
Length: 10 cm
Width: 4.6 cm
height: quite 1 cm

Hi to all,
this is a part of an open project.. that start here :)
The goal is to create a modular track for classic glass marbles. (16 mm diameter), but not only. Everyone can partecipate with fantasy, creating parts of the track, doing this "puzzle track" more and more funny. message me if you have question about. NOTE: soon I'll leave parametric measures of pieces, to let people add their own creations.
